choices.text: Type 1 collagen predominates in the early stage of wound healing.
Collagen undergoes remodelling at the end of first week
Type III collagen is weaker than type I collagen
Tensile strength of the wound is associated with its elastin content

questions.text: Which of the following statements about wound healing is true
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Type III collagen predominates in the early stage of wound healing which is weaker than late appearing type I( maturation stage). Remodelling occurs at the end of two weeks. Tensile strength of wound depends upon its collagen content.

choices.text: Keloids contain an excess of type B collagen.
The tensile strength of a scar reaches that of normal skin in around 2 years
Suture marks can be reduced by use of polyfilament sutures.
Elasticated garments and silicone gel sheeting have no role in management of keloids.

questions.text: Which of the following about scars is true
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Keloid contains type B collagen. The tensile strength of a scar never reaches that of normal skin. Suture marks are reduced by use of monofilament sutures.

questions.text: Partial Thickness loss of Skin is Which stage of Bed Sore ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Staging of Bed Sore : Stage I : Non Blanching Erythema. No Breach in Epidermis Stage II : Partial thickness loss of skin (Epidermis + Dermis) Stage III : Full Thickness skin loss, not through underlying fascia Stage IV : Exposed muscles ,Bones and Subcutaneous tissue.

questions.text: Most common Site of Pressure Sore is ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Most common site of pressure sore is Ischium Frequency of pressure sore : Ischium > Greater Trochanter > Sacrum > Heal > Lateral Malleolus > Medial Malleolus.

choices.text: It typically occurs on postoperative day 3
Salmon colored fluid coming out of the wound is the first sign of wound dehiscence
If evisceration occurs after wound dehiscence emergency abdominal closure is required
Reoperation is needed to avoid peritonitis.

questions.text: All of the following are true about wound dehiscence, EXCEPT:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Wound dehiscence is typically seen around postoperative day 5 to day 7 after open laparotomy. Option B: In the initial stages, the wound looks intact but large amounts of pink “salmon-colored” fluid are noted to be soaking the dressing, which is the first sign of wound dehiscence. This is peritoneal fluid. Option C: As evisceration is a catastrophic complication of wound dehiscence, where the skin itself opens up and the abdominal contents herniate. It typically happens when the patient (who may not have been recognized as having a dehiscence) coughs, strains, or gets out of bed. The patient must be kept in bed, and the bowel covered with large sterile dressings soaked with warm saline. Emergency abdominal closure is required. Option D: Reoperation is needed to avoid peritonitis and evisceration.

questions.text: In classification of contaminated wound which of the following is included ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: Tensile strength of the wound reaches that of the normal skin after ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The tensile strength of the wound never becomes normal or in other words it never reaches the tensile strength of the normal skin. Maximum tensile strength recovery after a wound is 80 % of that of normal skin, this is achieved after 3 months of the time since wound had occured.

questions.text: Delayed wound healing is seen in all except :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Hypertension does not delay the process of wound healing.

questions.text: Ratio of collagen type I to Type III at the end of remodelling phase is ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Predominant collagen deposited in proliferative phase is type III. In remodelling phase there is alignment of collagen type III and it is also replaced by collagen type I. At the end of remodelling phase collagen type I to Collagen type III is in the ratio of 4 : 1

questions.text: Criteria for viability of muscle are all except :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

choices.text: Separation of skin + subcutaneous tissue + fascia exposing tendons

questions.text: Degloving injury is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Degloving injury is an injury involving avulsion of the skin and the subcutaneous tissue from the underlying structures usually a result of trauma. As the blood supply to the skin is hampered the main concern is to retain the viability of the skin.

questions.text: Worst position of scar is ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The worst position of the scar is sternum as it has the maximum risk of formation of keloid in this position. The risk is maximum in the triangle formed between two shoulders and the sternum.

questions.text: Golden period for wound is ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The golden period for wound is 6 hours, It includes the time within which a fresh wound can be closed primarily Option A. Golden period for trauma is 1 hour Option C. Golden period for esophageal perforation is 24 hours. Esophageal perforations can be closed primarily in 24 hours since the time of perforation

choices.text: Shaving of the operative site before operation

questions.text: All of the following are the methods to reduce the surgical site infection except ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Preoperative shaving of the operative site increases the chances of surgical site infection rather than reducing it. What is advisable is preoperative clipping of hairs. Option A. Proper sterile technique is the corner stone of preventing surgical site infection Option C. Preoperative antibiotics are used to prevent the surgical site infection . Ideal time for giving preop prophylactic antibiotics is 1 hour before the operation or just at the time of induction of anesthesia. Option D. Use of monofilament sutures reduce the risk of surgical site infection.

choices.text: Large amount of necrotic tissue and eschar

questions.text: Which of the following is a contraindication for the procedure shown in this figure ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) This is a figure of vacuum associated dressing : Negative-pressure wound therapy (NPWT) is a therapeutic technique using a vacuum dressing to promote healing in acute or chronic wounds and enhance healing of second- and third-degree burns. The therapy involves the controlled application of sub-atmospheric pressure to the local wound environment, using a sealed wound dressing connected to a vacuum pump. NPWT appears to be useful for diabetic ulcers and management of the open abdomen (laparotomy) but further research is required for other wound types. Contraindications for NPWT : a. Malignancy in the wound b. Untreated osteomyelitis c. Non enteric unexplored fistula d. Necrotic tissue with eschar

questions.text: All of the following are the principles of negative pressure wound therapy except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Primary effects of NPWT is : Macrodeformation : Drawing the wound edges together leading to contraction. Stabilization of wound environment : Wound protection from outside micro-organisms in a warm and moist environment Reduced Edema: With removal of soft tissue exudates Microdeformation : Leading to cellular proliferation on the wound surface

choices.text: It appears a few weeks to months after surgery
It is limited in its distribution
It is common in old people

questions.text: What is true about keloids?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Keloid does not occurs just after the operation it occurs between 3 months to 3 years after the wound has occurred Option C. Keloid is not limited to the distribution of the scar, keloid tends to grow beyond the boundaries of the scar. Option D. Keloid is more common in the age group of 10- 30 years of age

choices.text: It has a strong genetic predisposition
It is more common on flexor aspects of the body
It is more common in the age group of 10- 30 years
It is more common in females.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the following condition is true ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) This figure show hypertrophic scar. Option A. Option A is wrong as this condition does not have a familial predisposition. Option B. This is true as hypertrophic scar is more common on the flexor aspects of the body Option C. This is false as hypertrophic scar is more common in children. Option D. Hypertrophic scar occurs equally in males and Females.

questions.text: Drug used for intralesional injection of keloid is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Triamcinolone intralesional injection is the most widely used treatment for keloid scars, primarily or after surgical excision, alone or in combination with 5-FU, verapamil and bleomycin. It is considered the gold standard in nonsurgical management of hypertrophic and keloid scars.

choices.text: Thorough cleaning with debridement of all dead and devitalized tissue without primary closure
Covering the defect with split skin graft after cleaning

questions.text: A patient with grossly contaminated wound presents 12 hours after an accident, his wound should be managed by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The golden period for wound is 6 hours, Patients presenting with wounds within 6 hours of injury: Thorough wash and debridement with primary closure of the wound. Patients presenting with wounds after 6 hours of injury: Thorough wash and debridement of the devitalized tissue but do not do primary closure.

questions.text: What is the main aim of performing a delayed primary repair ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Delayed wound closure should be used in wounds that are contaminated or contain devitalized tissue. The wound should be left open for three to four days for observation to determine if infection is present or if the tissues are devitalized. This management technique allows the physician to control infection and provide surgical debridement.. The wound then can be repaired with minimal risk of infection. Option B. This is wrong as in delayed primary closure the quality of the scar is poor as compared to primary closure of wound. Option C. Delayed primary closure does not lead to early healing of wound, in fact this has no effect on the time taken by the wound to heal.

questions.text: Percentage of surgical site infection rate in patient with clean contaminated wounds after antibiotics prophylaxis:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) SSI wounds are classified into following classes:- Class I=1 to 2% =Clean Wound, hollow viscera not opened.Example-breast/thyroid/ hernia Surgery CLASS II = CLASS III =10 TO 30% =CONTAMINATED, gross spillage from hollow viscera.Example- early accidental wound. CLASS IV =30 to 40 % =Dirty.Example-late accidental wound, pus, gangrene, fecal matter.

questions.text: Correct order of removing Personal Protective Equipment (PPE): 1. Gown 2. Mask 3. Face shield 4. Gloves
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Correct order of removing Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) is: 4. Gloves 1. Gown 3. Face shield 2. Mask

questions.text: Which of the following is not the component of qSOFA?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) qSOFA score includes the following:- 1.RR >22/min 2.Altered mental status 3.Systolic BP <100mmHg Bilateral pupillary reflex is not a component of qSOFA score.

questions.text: Which of the following scoring system is used for wound infection?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-SIRS Score as the name suggests,is for SIRS. Option B-ASA score is given for physical status of patient undergoing surgery. Option C-Southampton score is used for wound infection.The grading is given below. Option D-Glasgow coma score is used for neurological assessment.

questions.text: Best way to manage the wound shown in image is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-The given image shows Abrasion of epithelium and minor skin loss.It can heal spontaneously.hence,Cleaning and dressing is recommended in such situations. Option B-Debridement is done in cases of dead and necrotic tissue. Option C,D-skin grafting like allograft is not done in cases of abrasion.

questions.text: What is the correct order followed while hand washing: A. Back of hands B. Palm to palm C. Back of finger D. Fingernails
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The correct order followed while hand washing is: B. Palm to palm A. Back of hands C. Back of finger D. Fingernails

questions.text: What is the mechanism by which the following technique works?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The given image shows VAC DRESSING,also known as VACUUM ASSISTED CLOSURE. It has a negative pressure of -125mmHg.(Remember this value,It is another PYQ.) Conditions in which it is not used :- 1. Osteomyelits 2. Malignancies 3. Open abdomen, bowel directly visible

questions.text: Identify the grade of the bed score shown in the given below image?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Stage 1= ulcers have not yet broken through the skin. Stage 2= ulcers have a break in the top two layers of skin. Stage 3= ulcers affect the top two layers of skin, as well as fatty tissue. Stage 4= ulcers are deep wounds that may impact muscle, tendons, ligaments, and bone.

questions.text: In a covid positive patient who was symptomatic and recovered at home without hospital admission. Elective surgery in this patient can be planned after
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Since the patient was symptomatic but didn't required hospitalisation.Such a patient can be taken for surgery after 6 weeks.

choices.text: Pain on passive movements of the calf.

questions.text: Deep ulcer presented in the figure depicts?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The given image shows Trophic ulcer which occurs due to loss of sensation like as in diabetes.

questions.text: ER Open Cardiac massage is considered as what kind of wound
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) ER Open Cardiac massage is considered as contaminated kind of wound.

questions.text: ACCORDING TO BEDSORE (DECUBITUS ULCER) GRADING, PARTIAL THICKNESS SKIN INVOLVEMENT IS:-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Stage 1: just erythema of the skin. Stage 2: erythema with the loss of partial thickness of the skin including epidermis and part of the superficial dermis. Stage 3: full thickness ulcer that might involve the subcutaneous fat. Stage 4: full thickness ulcer with the involvement of the muscle.

choices.text: INCREASED DURATION OF HOSPITAL STAY BY 10 TO 30%
OPIOD SPARING ANALGESIA IS NOT PREFFERED

questions.text: WHICH AMONG THE FOLLOWING IS TRUE ABOUT ERAS PROTOCOL
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-ERAS (Enhanced Recovery After Surgery) protocols are multimodal perioperative care pathways designed to optimize patient recovery after surgery by minimizing the stress response and promoting early recovery. Option B-PROLONGED FASTING IS NOT MANDATORY IN ERAS. Option C-EARLY MOBILISATION IS RECOMMENDED. Option D-OPIOD SPARING ANALGESIA IS PREFFERED.

questions.text: POST LAPAROTOMY FOR PERFORATION PERITONITIS PATIENT ABDOMINAL WALL WAS CLOSED BUT SKIN WAS LEFT OPEN, WHICH WAS CLOSED ON 5th DAY. HOW THE HEALING OCCURS IN THIS CASE?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-Primary intention healing, also known as first intention healing, involves the rapid closure of a clean wound with minimal tissue loss, typically achieved by bringing the wound edges together with sutures, staples, or adhesive strips, resulting in a faster healing process and less scarring. Option B-Healing by secondary intention involves an open wound closing naturally from the base upwards, without direct closure, often used for wounds with large tissue loss or those that cannot be safely closed with stitches. Option C-Tertiary intention, also known as delayed primary closure, involves initially leaving a wound open to allow for debridement and observation, then closing it later when conditions are appropriate.

choices.text: Confirmation of patient identity and surgical site
Verification of antibiotics and blood transfusion requirements
Review of potential critical events and emergency procedures

questions.text: A 60-year-old male is scheduled for elective laparotomy for a bowel resection. As part of the preoperative protocol, the surgical team performs a surgical safety checklist. Which of the following elements is not typically included in the WHO Surgical Safety Checklist?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Review of anesthesia machine functionality The WHO Surgical Safety Checklist is designed to improve patient safety by minimizing the risks of surgical procedures through a structured preoperative protocol. It includes several critical elements to ensure the patient's safety and reduce the likelihood of preventable errors. The checklist is typically divided into three stages: before induction of anesthesia, before the incision, and before the patient leaves the operating room. Key elements typically included in the checklist: 1. Confirmation of patient identity and surgical site: Ensuring the correct patient is receiving the correct procedure. 2. Verification of antibiotics and blood transfusion requirements: Checking if the appropriate antibiotics are administered and ensuring blood is available if needed. 3. Review of potential critical events and emergency procedures: Discussing possible risks and complications specific to the surgery. 4. Surgical team members' names and roles: Confirming that everyone involved in the procedure knows their role and responsibilities.

choices.text: Well-defined lesion with low cellularity and minimal risk of recurrence
Ill-defined lesion with moderate cellularity and a moderate risk of recurrence
Well-defined lesion with moderate cellularity and low risk of recurrence
Ill-defined lesion with high cellularity and high risk of recurrence

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents with a large lipoma on her upper arm, and the surgeon decides to grade the lesion using the Southampton grading system. According to the Southampton grading system, what does a grade 3 lesion indicate?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Ill-defined lesion with high cellularity and high risk of recurrence The Southampton grading system is used to assess the risk of recurrence and malignancy in soft tissue tumors, especially lipomas. The grading system is based on histopathological characteristics, including the degree of cellularity, definition of the lesion, and the potential for recurrence. • Grade 3 lesions are ill-defined, show high cellularity, and have a high risk of recurrence. This indicates that the tumor is more aggressive and may require more extensive surgical treatment. • Grade 1 and Grade 2 lesions generally indicate lower risk, with well-defined borders and lower cellularity, suggesting a better prognosis with less chance of recurrence.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with a lipomatous lesion in his thigh. The lesion is well-defined with low cellularity on histopathological examination. Using the Southampton grading system, what is the most likely grade of the lesion?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Grade 1 In the Southampton grading system, Grade 1 is characterized by: • Well-defined lesion with low cellularity and minimal risk of recurrence. • These lesions are typically benign and have a low chance of regrowth after excision. The well-defined nature of the lesion and the low cellularity both suggest a benign nature, so this lesion would most likely be graded as Grade 1.
